reviewText: Every once in a while, I come across a movie that jerks me out of my normal hollywood funk ("hollywood funk"-the effects of watching various movies with virtually the same storyline repeatedly as if the plots were recycled for long periods of time) and reminds me what movies can be if enough thought, creativity, acting, care, and other special qualities are poured into the film.  "The Penitent Man" is one of those movies and and it's a relief because it's been a long, funky, dry spell.The movie has no special effects.  It has no explosions or car chases or stunts of any kind.  What this movie does have is superb acting (highlighted in this category is Lance Henrikson as he was in top form), strong scenes, creativity, and a great amount of story and imagination.I won't give anything away but you should give it a little over a half an hour.  If you don't like it by then, well...you'll know by then.  I strongly recommend this film for whatever my recommendation is worth.
Title: Penitent Man

reviewText: If the idea of listening to Lance Henriksen basically telling you a story that involves time travel, life lessons, and personal reflections for 45 minutes sounds interesting then this is the film you've always wanted. Henriksen is charming, interesting, and a fantastic storyteller- which is good because his telling of the story IS the story of the film. Unfortunately, despite a great scifi concept, the other actors in the movie are pretty terrible. The camera work changes from amateurish to expert. Overall, fundamentally uneven, but also bold in that it tackles a traditional science fiction concept and explores its ramification through a philosophical conversation. No wild visual effects, no flash cuts to the future, just Lance Henriksen's Mr. Darrell talking to his friend/psychologist, played by Lathrop Walker who is, in fact, an abysmal actor. The "reveal" is telegraphed very early and the ending is laughably bad and full of logical holes- ironically, none of which have to do with the often inscrutable subject of time travel. It is also notable that the end is devoid of Henriksen and thus anything resembling a credible performance. Watch at your own risk, though again Lance Henriksen's presence and delivery is great.
summary: Lance Henriksen is captivating, other actors- not so much.
Title: Penitent Man

reviewText: Lance Henriksen shines in this movie!He is an exceptional actor who brings this character to life.I reccomend this movie to anyone.
Title: Penitent Man

reviewText: I was in my home office, sorting items and decided to watch this film (on Netfix).  I always enjoy time travel films, my favorite being Millennium and another Canadian film about time tourists visiting disasters coming up second.This film is much more "cerebral" than the other two, but the performances were so good that I will recommend it.It was reminiscent of some of the old "Twilight Zone" TV shows with mini morality plays and concepts you could sink your teeth into.  Not as bombastic as "Looper," and a chance for the actors to really test their skills.  Nice job all around.If you can't live without explosions and car chases, and have difficulty follows other peoples' conversations, than skip this one.
summary: Like My Dinner With Andre and Time Travel
Title: Penitent Man

reviewText: The story starts out with delicious, tantalyzing indicators that it is going to be one of those excellent little independant films that comes along occasionally and threatens to tell us big truths.But the threat is never made good on because the writer (direct, producer, Nicholas Gyeney) hasn't gone far enough in his thinking to take us anywhere.Lance Henrikson is the one bright spot, making his character and the story believable as long as he is talking, and showing real depth and nuance.Lathrop Walker, local Seattle actor, just doesn't have enough of a character to work with and ends ups being whiney and sad....and, well... whiney.I hope this writer takes this up again in a few years. I have a feeling he does have a story to deliver when he puts the pieces together.
Title: Penitent Man
